title: [Mega-Post] Stealth And Vision In League (Includes An Infographic & Essay)
body:
I made an infographic (a real one this time) about stealth and vision in League. Hopefully it is informative and gives Riot something to think about.

https://orig00.deviantart.net/6382/f/2017/268/9/c/vision_stealth_graphic_final_by_drugsforrobots-dboiqcr.png

I also wrote [this 20+ page essay](https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vTJsB8hmNMil_LeaNJmmUh62EKI2W58Ma_QaO0oeKsl1QUZiZnoh5xW6KO9rCZkLgh2o6WEEs7r1ozc/pub) about stealth and vision as a companion piece to this infographic. Hopefully it elaborates and illuminates my thinking on the subject and gives Riot food for thought.

Edit: [X-Post on Reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/72dx04/megapost_stealth_vision_in_league_includes/).

replies.body:
Slight nit-picking, but there are a lot of AoE, non directly vision-related abilities that give vision in their AoE. Counting Darius separately just because his AoE happens to be a cone seems a bit arbitrary, especially since it's 99.9% of the time NOT used to get vision.

Also, what do you mean with "capable of stealth gameplay"? For instance, I don't see what Annie or Braum or Draven do in that list. Gut feeling is your definition might be a bit too large to be relevant.
Stealth gameplay probably means hiding in bushes. ASol hardly counts for this since his passive shows even if he's in a bush

ASol can still engage in stealthy play. He just has to work harder at it. The ASol player has to be mindful of his stars, but as long as he or she is attempting to gain an information advantage over his / her opponent, i.e. maintaining vision on them while denying sight of his/herself, then that is stealth gameplay.

I wanted to be accurate, thus I counted Darius' Apprehend. It should raise the question though, why are there so few cones of vision? 

Stealth is behavior. It requires a certain mindset. Certain elements in League, like brush and terrain, offer concealment, and are therefore conducive to stealth gameplay. Another example, though I can't find the video, was of a Korean Elise being told the river was warded. Her ally pinged out the exact spot of the ward, and the Elise, understanding the vision system, knew that given its location she could skirt around it, just out of it's sight range. She did just that, remained unseen, and flanked the enemy mid-laner. She was using stealth in the true sense of the word.

Stealth gameplay is not possible in every game. There has to be a certain critical mass of mechanics and elements - the game's systems have to be conducive to stealth gameplay. Games like Doom (1997 or 2016) don't have the systems in place to support stealth gameplay, despite a player's best attempts at sneaking up on enemies and using cover / terrain to deny line-of-sight.
yeah {{champion:99}} E & R and much more

Both the infographic and the essay are tremendously good work, and I thank you very much for posting this! I very much agree with what you said: stealth gameplay in League is full of potential, but heavily underdeveloped, and I agree that part of it comes from the MMO design of stealth being implemented purely as invisibility. I also very much agree that vision is similarly not implemented in the most interesting manner: wards are utterly boring, and I feel one of the reasons why there's such a discrepancy across ranked divisions in their usage, and the associated quality of play in the game, isn't so much because people don't know how to use them, as it is that most care so little about them as a gameplay effect that they have to actively remind themselves to ward, as it very much comes across as a chore rather than an interesting activity. 

On top of that, though, champion abilities capable of revealing opponents often do so out of convenience, instead of truly contributing vision or detection as a unique, powerful asset, and this I think has led to a fair degree of (ironically) invisible power, where some effects just happen to have an impact cue or reveal attached, and where champions who would normally comes across as vision providers don't really fulfil that theme (Lux, for example, only reveals with her E and ult). Building upon both stealth and vision systems could add a whole new layer of gameplay what would come particularly in handy when designing and balancing assassins.

Thank you. As always you said as much or more than I could in fewer words! XD

Rat needs some nerfs, bad.   I mostly think that his stealth radius is far too low, and effectively bypasses what is supposed to be the counterplay to camouflage based stealth, the chance to react before damage is dealt.  Either his base AA range should go down a bit, and be re-granted in his ult, or his stealth spotted radius should significantly increase, to something like 900 units, which would be outside of his max distance ult AA range.

I think Twitch should leave a puff of "smell" every three seconds he's in stealth or something so you can suddenly see the sign and be on guard but if he's still moving then you won't know where he is exactly, just that he's nearby and where he just was.

I think audio cues would work better for Twitch - like he talks to himself out-loud, maybe he'd have specific lines that the Twitch player and his enemies knew he would say at certain distances or at certain points in time while he was invis.

And not to be that guy, but we really should say, "while he's invisible" because you can be invisible and not be stealthy.
I personally don't like audio queues. I think visual queues are almost always better

I don't think that's necessarily true. I imagine Riot could give Eve an audio cue that increased in volume based on her proximity (distance to them) and stalking duration (time near them) that would be just enough to clue players in. I don't think she needs a visual clue however, as her current detection radius is enough. For an audio cue, I imagine 'night whispers'. They wouldn't ever be as loud as a champion's voicelines, but they'd at least be something. And during a hectic teamfight with all the SFX from spells and abilities, and players trying to voice com, I think she would do fine.

All that would do is make her bad at high elo where people have an absolutely massive attention to detail generally, and good at low elo, where people are frequently as blind as a mole rat, assuming she got compensation buffs that she would clearly need because you just pointlessly nerfed an already mediocre champion.
People keep making a similar argument, but I want to see it tested. AFAIK, nothing like that has ever been tried, and Riot has instead relied on a system of hard-counters.

Well Shaco does have an evil laugh upon disappearing, but Riot won't emphasize it or his puff of smoke when he uses Q. Rather than give his invis-ability this form of counterplay, they nerfed his invis duration and his damage.

I personally think you should be able to hear Shaco Q within a huge range (~2000 units?) and you should be able to hear his Boxes as well. These forms of counterplay would mean he could afford to have more damage (and not be countered by a FREE or 75g item.)

Shaco's Q stealth is true invisibility, control wards don't reveal it.  They will make the boxes easy to kill though, but they need counterplay anyway because those things are absolutely nightmarish to play against if the Shaco builds AP, due to their high ratio and consistent dps over a few seconds.

I was referring to the now defunct Vision Ward, which was Riot's solution for... 4-5 years? Which should prove my point: rather than giving his abilities better / more counterplay, they'd sooner give player's a FREE or 75g item to counter Shaco.

To add insult to injury, they proved they are willing to change his abilities, but they didn't change them in ways that would've given Shaco's opponent's better counterplay - they effectively just amounted to nerfs.

To be honest, Riot could easily add True Vision to several abilities .eg. Ashe E, Quinn W.

Would help alleviate some pressure.
I would like to see more True Sight in League, but it needs to be clear when a champion is under the effects of True Sight. They need to use the appropriate / clear icons and indicators.
Like when {{champion:4}}  Has his R icon above your head?

It's not clear to the player that the effect is True Sight. I want to see a sort of icon appear next to their health bar like what RIot has done for the various CC effects. TF is definitely not the worse case though.
It's up to the player to find out what champions abilities kits and skills entail though. Like mordekaisers Q. If you don't know that you shouldn't let him hit you more than twice well.....

You can call it semantics if you wish, but as I try to explain in my essay, the people who make the best stealth games (Thief, Hitman, Dishonored, Splinter Cell, MGS, etc.) are all working with a definition of stealth as gameplay - as player behavior. Riot, on the other hand, seems to limit themselves to thinking of stealth only as a handful of mechanics specific to certain champions. This is why they seem to struggle how to balance or what to do with stealth. As they don't think of stealth gameplay, they aren't implementing enough mechanics or elements or using their systems (like audio) to support stealth gameplay. Despite that though, League is the most conducive to stealth gameplay of all the MOBAs / RTSs.

I'd disagree on your last statement, out of all the MOBAs I'd say HotS pulls of stealth best with it's shimmer solution. It gives the most skillful counter play, if a player is aware of their surroundings they will most certainly be able to see the stealth character and a lot of the time punish them for being out of position when they were relying on their stealth. Conversely, a stealth hero can make a good decision on their timing to go in when someone isn't paying attention to get the jump on them. Not to mention, if a stealth hero is careless they'll be revealed by a stray skillshot or aoe.
